questions.text: Michaelis Gutmann bodies are seen in
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Malakoplakia is a distinctive chronic inflammatory reaction that appears to stem from acquired defects in phagocyte function, malakoplakia arises in the setting of chronic bacterial infection, mostly by E. coli or occasionally Proteus species. It occurs with increased frequency in immunosuppressed transplant recipients. In the bladder, malakoplakia takes the form of soft, yellow, slightly raised mucosal plaques, 3 to 4 cm in diameter, that are filled with large, foamy macrophages mixed with occasional multinucleate giant cells and lymphocytes. The macrophages have an abundant granular cytoplasm due to phagosomes stuffed with particulate and membranous debris of bacterial origin. In addition, laminated mineralized concretions resulting from deposition of calcium in enlarged lysosomes, known as Michaelis-Gutmann bodies, are

choices.text: Linear deposits along glomerular basement membrane

questions.text: Seen in post streptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSGN)?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Subepithelial deposits. In post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSGN), one of the hallmark features is the presence of subepithelial deposits. These deposits are composed of immune complexes and are visible on electron microscopy as humps on the glomerular basement membrane (GBM). These humps are formed as a result of the immune response following a streptococcal infection, where antibodies form complexes with streptococcal antigens, leading to their deposition in the glomeruli. This deposition contributes to the characteristic inflammatory response seen in PSGN. Explanation for Incorrect Answers: A. Nephrotic range proteinuria While proteinuria is a common feature in PSGN, the proteinuria in this condition is typically not in the nephrotic range. PSGN more often presents with mild to moderate proteinuria and is classically associated with hematuria, red blood cell casts, and azotemia. Nephrotic-range proteinuria is more commonly seen in other conditions like minimal change disease or membranous nephropathy. B. Neutrophilic infiltration of tubules Neutrophilic infiltration in the tubules is more characteristic of acute pyelonephritis or certain other forms of acute glomerulonephritis, but it is not a defining feature of PSGN. In PSGN, the main inflammatory cells are monocytes/macrophages, and the characteristic finding in the glomeruli is the immune complex deposition, not neutrophilic infiltration. D. Linear deposits along glomerular basement membrane Linear deposits along the glomerular basement membrane are seen in anti-GBM disease (Goodpasture syndrome), not in PSGN. In anti-GBM disease, IgG antibodies specifically target the glomerular basement membrane, leading to linear staining on immunofluorescence. In contrast, PSGN involves granular deposition of immunoglobulins (primarily IgG and C3) in a subepithelial location, not linear staining along the GBM.

questions.text: Most common renal lesions in HIV:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) FSGS (Focal Segmental Glomerulosclerosis). Focal Segmental Glomerulosclerosis (FSGS) is the most common renal lesion seen in patients with HIV infection. HIV-associated nephropathy (HIVAN) is a specific form of kidney disease linked to HIV infection, and it often presents with FSGS. This condition is characterized by focal (affecting some glomeruli) and segmental (only parts of the glomerulus) scarring. The pathogenesis of HIVAN involves the direct infection of podocytes by the virus, leading to damage and subsequent glomerular sclerosis. FSGS is commonly observed in HIV-positive patients, particularly those with poorly controlled viral loads, and it can lead to nephrotic syndrome, proteinuria, and rapid renal deterioration. Incorrect Options: A. MPGN (Membranoproliferative Glomerulonephritis) Membranoproliferative Glomerulonephritis (MPGN) is a type of glomerulonephritis characterized by mesangial cell proliferation and thickening of the glomerular basement membrane. While MPGN can occur in HIV-infected patients, it is much less common than FSGS. MPGN is often associated with chronic infections and autoimmune diseases, and while it can occasionally be seen in the context of HIV, it is not the most frequent renal lesion in this population. B. RPGN (Rapidly Progressive Glomerulonephritis) Rapidly Progressive Glomerulonephritis (RPGN) refers to a clinical syndrome characterized by rapid loss of kidney function, often associated with crescent formation in the glomeruli. While RPGN can occur in patients with HIV, it is not the most common renal lesion in this population. FSGS is much more prevalent in HIV-infected patients, and RPGN is typically linked to other causes, such as Goodpasture syndrome or ANCA-associated vasculitis, rather than being a typical feature of HIVAN. D. Membranous nephropathy Membranous nephropathy is a kidney condition in which there is thickening of the glomerular basement membrane due to the deposition of immune complexes. It can occur in HIV-positive individuals, particularly in those with chronic HIV infection or coinfection with other viruses like hepatitis B or hepatitis C. However, it is much less common than FSGS in the context of HIV infection. While membranous nephropathy can present with nephrotic syndrome, FSGS remains the most frequent renal lesion seen in HIV-infected patients.

questions.text: Which is seen in Electron microscopy in PSGN?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Subepithelial humps. In post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSGN), the characteristic finding on electron microscopy is the presence of subepithelial humps. These humps represent immune complex deposits that are located beneath the epithelial layer of the glomerular basement membrane (GBM). They form due to the deposition of antigen-antibody complexes following a streptococcal infection, which triggers an immune response. These subepithelial deposits are often seen as irregular, hump-like structures under electron microscopy and are a defining feature of PSGN. Explanation for Incorrect Answers: B. Spike and dome appearance The spike and dome appearance is seen in membranous nephropathy, not PSGN. It refers to the appearance of the glomerular basement membrane (GBM) on electron microscopy, where the immune complexes deposited on the epithelial side of the GBM cause the basement membrane to form spike-like projections. This appearance is characteristic of membranous nephropathy, not PSGN. C. Mesangial deposits Mesangial deposits are commonly seen in IgA nephropathy or membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis (MPGN) but are not a hallmark of PSGN. In PSGN, the primary deposition occurs in the subepithelial space, not in the mesangium. The presence of mesangial deposits would not be a typical feature of PSGN. D. Subendothelial deposits Subendothelial deposits are typically seen in conditions like systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) or membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis (MPGN), not in PSGN. In PSGN, the deposits are located in the subepithelial space, not under the endothelium. Subendothelial deposits are characteristic of immune complex diseases where the complexes are deposited between the endothelium and the basement membrane, but this is not a feature of PSGN.

questions.text: Increased levels of C3NeF are associated with?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Also called Dense Deposit Disease Most patients with dense-deposit disease (formerly called type II MPGN) have abnormalities resulting in excessive activation of the alternative complement pathway. These patients have a consistently decreased serum C3 but normal C1 and C4, the early components of complement. They also have diminished serum levels of Factor B and properdin, components of the alternative complement pathway. In the glomeruli, C3 and properdin are deposited, but IgG is not. Recall that in the alternative complement pathway, C3 is directly cleaved to C3b. The reaction depends on the initial activation of C3 by such substances as bacterial polysaccharides, endotoxin, and aggregates of IgA via a pathway involving Factors B and D. This leads to the generation of C3bBb, the alternative pathway C3 convertase. Normally, this C3 convertase is labile, but more than 70% of patients with dense-deposit disease have a circulating autoantibody termed C3 nephritic factor (C3NeF) that binds the alternative pathway C3 convertase and protects it from inactivation. This favors persistent C3 activation and hypocomplementemia.

questions.text: A 60-years-old male with complaints for frothy urine and facial puffiness. The DIF and electron microscopic picture of the patient is given below. Diagnosis is?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Membranous glomerulopathy. Membranous glomerulopathy (also known as membranous nephropathy) is characterized by thickening of the glomerular basement membrane due to the deposition of immune complexes. This is typically seen in patients with nephrotic syndrome, which can present with symptoms such as frothy urine and facial puffiness due to proteinuria. The diagnosis of membranous nephropathy can be confirmed through direct immunofluorescence (DIF) showing granular deposits of IgG and C3 along the glomerular capillary walls. Electron microscopy often reveals subepithelial immune complex deposits and spike-and-dome formations on the glomerular basement membrane. This combination of findings, along with clinical symptoms, strongly points to membranous nephropathy as the diagnosis. Incorrect Options: A. Membranoproliferative nephritis Membranoproliferative nephritis (MPGN) is characterized by mesangial cell proliferation and thickening of the glomerular basement membrane, but it typically shows "tram-track" appearance on light microscopy due to duplication of the basement membrane. The immunofluorescence pattern is often granular, but it is not typically associated with the subepithelial deposits seen in membranous glomerulopathy. Additionally, MPGN is more commonly associated with chronic infections or autoimmune diseases, not the typical presentation of frothy urine and facial puffiness. C. Minimal change disease Minimal change disease (MCD) typically presents with nephrotic syndrome and is the most common cause of nephrotic syndrome in children, though it can also occur in adults. On light microscopy, there is usually no significant change in the glomeruli, hence the name "minimal change." Electron microscopy in MCD shows fusion of podocyte foot processes but not the immune complex deposits seen in membranous nephropathy. Minimal change disease usually lacks the thickening of the basement membrane seen in membranous glomerulopathy. D. FSGS (Focal Segmental Glomerulosclerosis) Focal Segmental Glomerulosclerosis (FSGS) is a common cause of nephrotic syndrome in adults, but it is characterized by segmental scarring of glomeruli and loss of podocytes. On light microscopy, there is evidence of segmental sclerosis in some glomeruli, and electron microscopy shows foot process effacement. The immune deposits that characterize membranous nephropathy are not seen in FSGS, and granular deposits of IgG on immunofluorescence would not be typical of FSGS

questions.text: Collapsing variant of FSGS is seen in:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) HIV. The collapsing variant of Focal Segmental Glomerulosclerosis (FSGS) is a distinctive subtype of FSGS characterized by collapse and fibrosis of the glomerular tufts, often with severe podocyte injury. This variant is most commonly seen in patients with HIV infection, particularly those with HIV-associated nephropathy (HIVAN). The collapsing variant is strongly associated with poorly controlled HIV and is one of the most severe forms of kidney disease seen in HIV-infected patients. The pathology of HIVAN often includes glomerular collapse, tubular microcyst formation, and significant podocyte effacement on electron microscopy. This variant leads to significant proteinuria and rapid kidney dysfunction in affected individuals. Incorrect Options: A. NSAIDs (Nonsteroidal Anti-inflammatory Drugs) NSAIDs are known to cause kidney damage, especially in the form of acute interstitial nephritis, chronic kidney disease, and nephrotic syndrome. However, they are not typically associated with the collapsing variant of FSGS. FSGS related to NSAIDs is more commonly seen in the non-collapsing form, and the collapsing variant is not a known consequence of NSAID use. B. Heroin abuse Heroin abuse can lead to kidney disease, particularly due to focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS) and nephrotic syndrome, often in the form of the non-collapsing variant. Heroin-associated nephropathy (HAN) is associated with classic FSGS, but it is not commonly linked to the collapsing variant of FSGS. This variant is more closely tied to HIV infection, rather than heroin use. D. CMV (Cytomegalovirus) Cytomegalovirus (CMV) is a viral infection that can affect multiple organs, including the kidneys. While CMV may cause renal tubular damage or glomerulitis, it is not typically associated with the collapsing variant of FSGS. CMV-related kidney disease tends to manifest with interstitial nephritis or acute kidney injury, and the collapsing variant of FSGS is more commonly seen in HIV infection.

questions.text: A 50-years-old male presented with blurring of vision. Urine examination showed proteinuria. Fundus examination showed dot and blot haemorrhages, microaneurysm and cotton wool spots. Histopathology pic of kidney given below. Your diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Kimmelstiel-Wilson nodules. The clinical presentation in this case is highly suggestive of diabetic nephropathy, a complication of diabetes mellitus. The patient presents with blurring of vision, which is a common symptom in patients with diabetic retinopathy. The urine examination showing proteinuria and the fundus findings of dot and blot hemorrhages, microaneurysms, and cotton wool spots are characteristic of diabetic retinopathy. Histopathological examination of the kidney showing Kimmelstiel-Wilson nodules supports this diagnosis. These nodules are a key finding in diabetic nephropathy and are characterized by eosinophilic, hyaline deposits in the glomeruli. The nodules are typically located in the mesangium and are considered a hallmark of advanced diabetic glomerulosclerosis. Incorrect Options: B. Crescents Crescent formation in the glomeruli is typically seen in rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis (RPGN), especially in anti-glomerular basement membrane disease, lupus nephritis, and vasculitis. Crescents are formed by the accumulation of proliferating epithelial cells and inflammatory cells in the Bowman's capsule. The clinical presentation in this case does not match the typical findings for RPGN, and the histopathology does not show crescent formation, making this an incorrect option. C. Amyloid Amyloidosis is a condition characterized by the deposition of abnormal protein aggregates (amyloid) in various organs, including the kidneys. In the kidneys, amyloid deposits are typically seen in the mesangium and glomerular basement membrane. Amyloid nephropathy usually presents with nephrotic syndrome, and the histopathological features would include apple-green birefringence under polarized light with Congo red staining. The presentation in this case is not typical for amyloidosis, and the histopathological findings do not suggest amyloid deposits. D. Segmental sclerosis Segmental glomerulosclerosis is a feature of focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS), a disease that leads to glomerular scarring in some segments of the glomeruli. FSGS typically presents with nephrotic syndrome, and the histopathological finding of segmental sclerosis would be seen. However, FSGS is not commonly associated with the characteristic fundus findings or the Kimmelstiel-Wilson nodules seen in this patient, making it less likely compared to diabetic nephropathy.

questions.text: The intra cytoplasmic vacuoles seen in the Armanni Epstein cell are rich in
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Armanni-Ebstein lesions were first described by Luciano Armanni, a pathologist at the University of Naples, during autopsy studies undertaken in 1872, as a unique vacuolar nephropathy associated with poorly controlled diabetes that involves selective renal epithelial cell glycogen accumulation. However, within the last two decades, a broader range of vacuolar changes, including lipid deposition, have also been termed Armanni-Ebstein (AE) lesions, creating some confusion on possible etiology. The term AE phenomenon is best reserved for the original clear cell change associated with glycogen deposition, and that this should be clearly distinguished from subnuclear lipid vacuolization («basal vacuolization»).

questions.text: A 40-years-old hypertensive male was admitted to the hospital with sudden onset of headache and altered sensorium. On Examination his Blood Pressure was observed to be 220/110mm Hg and the patient died four hours later. What is likely pathological finding in his kidneys
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) The history is suggestive of malignant hypertension. The kidney size varies depending on the duration and severity of the hypertensive disease. Small, pinpoint petechial hemorrhages may appear on the cortical surface from rupture of arterioles or glomerular capillaries, giving the kidney a peculiar “flea-bitten” appearance.

questions.text: Most common gene associated with renal cell carcinoma is?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) VHL. The most common genetic mutation associated with renal cell carcinoma (RCC) is a mutation in the VHL gene (Von Hippel-Lindau gene). This gene is located on chromosome 3p and plays a crucial role in regulating hypoxia-inducible factors (HIFs), which control various processes, including vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF) expression. When the VHL gene is mutated or deleted, it leads to unregulated HIF expression, resulting in angiogenesis and tumor formation. The VHL gene mutation is most commonly seen in sporadic RCC and is also associated with the genetic condition Von Hippel-Lindau syndrome, which predisposes individuals to develop multiple types of tumors, including renal cell carcinoma. Incorrect Options: A. WT-1 The WT1 gene is associated with Wilms' tumor, a common pediatric renal tumor. Mutations in the WT1 gene are not typically associated with renal cell carcinoma but are instead linked to Wilms' tumor, which arises from nephrogenic rests in children. While WT1 mutations may be implicated in some cases of glomerulosclerosis and Wilms' tumor, they are not a major cause of renal cell carcinoma, making this an incorrect answer. B. BRCA-1 The BRCA1 gene is a well-known tumor suppressor gene that is most commonly associated with breast cancer and ovarian cancer. Although mutations in BRCA1 can increase the risk of certain other cancers, including prostate cancer, it is not typically associated with renal cell carcinoma. BRCA2, on the other hand, has been more closely linked to an increased risk of renal cell carcinoma, but BRCA1 mutations do not play a significant role in RCC pathogenesis. D. PATCH The PATCH gene is part of the Hedgehog signaling pathway, which is involved in embryonic development and tissue repair. Mutations in PATCH are more commonly associated with basal cell carcinoma and other skin cancers rather than renal cell carcinoma. While Hedgehog signaling can be involved in various tumors, including some types of RCC, it is not the most common genetic alteration seen in renal cell carcinoma, making this an incorrect choice..

questions.text: Chromophobe variant of renal cell carcinoma is associated with:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Chromophobe carcinoma represents 5% of renal cell cancers and is composed of cells with prominent cell membranes and pale eosinophilic cytoplasm, usually with a halo around the nucleus. On cytogenetic examination these tumors show multiple chromosome losses and extreme hypodiploidy. Like the benign oncocytoma, they are thought to grow from intercalated cells of collecting ducts and have an excellent prognosis compared with that of the clear cell and papillary cancers. Histologic distinction from oncocytoma can be difficult.

questions.text: Cylindrical dilations of renal tubules is seen in
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Autosomal Recessive Polycystic Kidney Disease (ARPKD). Autosomal Recessive Polycystic Kidney Disease (ARPKD) is characterized by cylindrical dilations of renal tubules. This condition is a genetic disorder that primarily affects the kidneys and liver. In ARPKD, dilated renal tubules are a key histological feature, particularly in the cortex and medulla of the kidney. The dilation of the tubules is due to the formation of cysts, but the cysts in ARPKD are often smaller and more diffusely distributed compared to the large cysts seen in Autosomal Dominant Polycystic Kidney Disease (ADPKD). This feature of cylindrical dilations is a hallmark of ARPKD, making this the correct answer. Incorrect Options: B. Medullary Cystic Disease Medullary cystic disease is a type of kidney disease that results in the formation of medullary cysts. These cysts are typically located in the renal medulla and often lead to fibrosis and progressive renal insufficiency. However, cylindrical dilations of renal tubules are not a typical feature of medullary cystic disease. The disease is more characterized by the formation of cysts and the progressive damage to the kidneys without the tubular dilatation seen in ARPKD. Therefore, this is not the correct answer. C. Autosomal Dominant Polycystic Kidney Disease (ADPKD) Autosomal Dominant Polycystic Kidney Disease (ADPKD) is characterized by the presence of large cysts in the kidneys that progressively enlarge over time, leading to kidney dysfunction. While cystic changes are a hallmark of ADPKD, it does not primarily involve cylindrical dilations of renal tubules. ADPKD's cysts are typically spherical rather than cylindrical, and the cysts are not typically found in the tubular structure as seen in ARPKD. This makes ADPKD an incorrect answer in the context of cylindrical dilations. D. Lipoid Nephrosis Lipoid nephrosis, also known as minimal change disease, is primarily associated with nephrotic syndrome and characterized by proteinuria, edema, and hypoalbuminemia. Histologically, it shows foot process effacement of the podocytes on electron microscopy, but it does not typically involve cylindrical dilations of renal tubules. Instead, the primary changes in lipoid nephrosis are related to the glomeruli, not the tubules, making this an incorrect option.

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman complains of severe headaches anddizziness. The patient has a history of repeated urinary tractinfections. The blood pressure is 180/110 mm Hg. Laboratorystudies show elevated levels of BUN (38 mg/ dL) and creatinine(2.8 mg/dL). A CT scan of the lower abdomen reveals small,irregularly shaped kidneys with deep coarse scars. A percutaneousrenal biopsy is shown. Which of the following is theappropriate diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Thyroidisation of tubules is seen in chronic pyelonephritis. The microscopic changes involve predominantly tubules and interstitium. The tubules show atrophy in some areas and hypertrophy or dilation in others. Dilated tubules with flattened epithelium may be filled with casts resembling thyroid colloid (thyroidization). There are varying degrees of chronic interstitial inflammation and fibrosis in the cortex and medulla.

questions.text: Childhood polycystic kidney disease is -
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Autosomal Recessive. Childhood polycystic kidney disease (PKD) refers to Autosomal Recessive Polycystic Kidney Disease (ARPKD). ARPKD is a genetic disorder that typically presents in infancy or early childhood. It is caused by mutations in the PKHD1 gene located on chromosome 6p12, which codes for the fibrocystin protein. This condition is characterized by bilateral kidney cysts and can result in renal failure early in life, sometimes even in utero or shortly after birth. The inheritance pattern is autosomal recessive, meaning that both parents must carry the defective gene for a child to be affected. Incorrect Options: A. Autosomal Dominant Autosomal Dominant Polycystic Kidney Disease (ADPKD) is the more common form of polycystic kidney disease, but it typically manifests in adulthood, often in the 30s to 40s. It is caused by mutations in the PKD1 or PKD2 genes. In contrast to ARPKD, ADPKD is not typically seen in childhood, but rather as a progressive disease in adults. Therefore, this is not the correct answer for childhood PKD. C. X-linked X-linked inheritance refers to conditions where the gene involved is located on the X chromosome. While there are some X-linked disorders that affect the kidneys, polycystic kidney disease is not typically X-linked. Thus, this is not the correct answer for childhood polycystic kidney disease. D. Multifactorial genetic disease A multifactorial genetic disease involves both genetic and environmental factors, and while polycystic kidney disease may have environmental components in its progression, it is primarily inherited in an autosomal recessive (ARPKD) or autosomal dominant (ADPKD) pattern. Therefore, ARPKD is not classified as multifactorial, making this an incorrect choice.

questions.text: Most common cause of nephrotic syndrome in elderly
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Membranous Glomerulopathy. In elderly individuals, membranous glomerulopathy (also known as membranous nephropathy) is the most common cause of nephrotic syndrome. This condition is typically characterized by thickening of the glomerular basement membrane and is most often associated with autoimmune diseases or malignancies in older adults. Membranous nephropathy is more common in elderly males and can present with nephrotic syndrome that includes proteinuria, edema, and hypoalbuminemia. It is associated with the presence of anti-phospholipase A2 receptor antibodies in most cases, which play a role in the disease process. This makes membranous glomerulopathy the correct answer for the most common cause of nephrotic syndrome in the elderly. Incorrect Options: B. Minimal Change Disease Minimal change disease is a well-known cause of nephrotic syndrome, but it is more commonly seen in children than in the elderly. In elderly individuals, minimal change disease is less common as a cause of nephrotic syndrome compared to other conditions like membranous nephropathy. Therefore, this is not the correct answer for elderly patients. C. Acute Glomerulonephritis (GN) Acute glomerulonephritis typically presents as acute kidney injury and is often associated with hematuria, oliguria, and hypertension, rather than nephrotic syndrome, which is characterized by proteinuria. Although acute GN can occur in elderly individuals, it is not the most common cause of nephrotic syndrome in this age group. This makes acute GN an incorrect choice for this particular question. D. Focal Segmental Glomerulosclerosis (FSGS) Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS) is a cause of nephrotic syndrome, but it is more commonly seen in younger adults or those with secondary causes such as obesity or HIV infection. It is not the most common cause of nephrotic syndrome in the elderly, where conditions like membranous glomerulopathy are more prevalent. Therefore, FSGS is not the correct answer for the elderly population.

choices.text: Basket weave pattern of the basement membrane

questions.text: An 8 year old male patient with history of hematuria 3 days after contracting a respiratory infection is being evaluated. Which of the following is most likely to be the electron microscopy finding?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Since the history is short, the possibility of acquiring IgA nephropathy is higher. It is characterised by mesangial deposits. Same h/o with development of symptoms after 1week will make the diagnosis as PSGN

questions.text: Rapid advanced renal parameters is clinically termed as Rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis. What exactly is the finding on microscopy?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Crescents. In rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis (RPGN), the hallmark finding on microscopy is the presence of crescents in the glomeruli. These crescents are formed due to the accumulation of proliferating cells, fibrin, and extracellular matrix within the Bowman’s capsule in response to severe glomerular injury. The crescent formation is a result of the inflammatory process and is associated with a rapid decline in kidney function. This feature is critical in the diagnosis of RPGN, and it indicates a poor prognosis if not treated promptly. Explanation for Incorrect Answers: A. Membrane thickening Membrane thickening is typically seen in diseases like membranous nephropathy, where there is thickening of the glomerular basement membrane due to immune complex deposition. It is not characteristic of RPGN, where the key feature is crescent formation. B. Segmental sclerosis Segmental sclerosis refers to areas of scarring within the glomeruli and is most often seen in conditions such as focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS). While it represents glomerular injury, it is not a defining feature of RPGN, which instead shows crescents due to the acute inflammatory process. D. Mesangial expansion Mesangial expansion is commonly seen in diseases like diabetic nephropathy or IgA nephropathy, where there is increased mesangial matrix or cellularity. It is not associated with RPGN, where the dominant finding is crescent formation

questions.text: Which of the following disease has deafness as well as hematuria?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Alport syndrome, when fully developed, is manifest by hematuria with progression to chronic renal failure, accompanied by nerve deafness and various eye disorders, including lens dislocation, posterior cataracts, and corneal dystrophy. The disease is inherited as an X-linked trait in approximately 85% of cases. In the X-linked form, males express the full syndrome, while female heterozygotes typically present with hematuria. Approximately 90% of affected males progress to ESRD before 40 years of age. Autosomal recessive and autosomal dominant pedigrees also exist, in which males and females are equally susceptible to the full syndrome

questions.text: In renal biopsy of a 14 years old boy with nephritic syndrome, glomeruli are showing proliferation of mesangial cells with GBM thickening and mesangial cell interposition. What is the most likely diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Mesangiocapillary glomerulonephritis (MCGN), also known as membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis (MPGN). In this case, the histologic findings of mesangial cell proliferation, glomerular basement membrane (GBM) thickening, and mesangial cell interposition are characteristic of mesangiocapillary glomerulonephritis (MCGN). This type of glomerulonephritis typically presents with nephritic syndrome and is commonly seen in children. The pathophysiology of MCGN involves immune complex deposition within the mesangium and subendothelial space, leading to the proliferation of mesangial cells and thickening of the GBM. Explanation for Incorrect Answers: A. Membranous nephropathy Membranous nephropathy is characterized by thickening of the glomerular basement membrane due to immune complex deposition. However, it does not show the mesangial cell proliferation or mesangial cell interposition seen in this case. Membranous nephropathy typically leads to nephrotic syndrome and is not typically associated with nephritic syndrome in children. B. Diffuse proliferative glomerulonephritis Diffuse proliferative glomerulonephritis (DPGN) is a term used for glomerulonephritis with widespread glomerular proliferation, often seen in lupus nephritis. It may show endocapillary proliferation (increase in cells within the capillary loops), but it does not typically present with mesangial proliferation, GBM thickening, or mesangial cell interposition, which are features seen in MCGN. C. Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS) is characterized by focal scarring (sclerosis) of some but not all glomeruli, and some glomeruli show segmental sclerosis. It is not associated with mesangial proliferation or mesangial interposition and usually presents with nephrotic syndrome. The findings in this case are more consistent with MCGN.

questions.text: Dysmorphic RBC with ARF is seen in?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Glomerular disease. In glomerular diseases, such as glomerulonephritis, the presence of dysmorphic red blood cells (RBCs) is commonly observed, particularly when there is glomerular injury. Dysmorphic RBCs are typically fragmented or irregular in shape due to the mechanical damage as they pass through the glomerular capillaries under abnormal conditions, such as in the case of glomerular inflammation or crescent formation. This is a key diagnostic feature in nephritic syndrome, where there is both hematuria and acute renal failure (ARF). Explanation for Incorrect Answers: B. Renal carcinoma While renal carcinoma can cause hematuria, it is not associated with dysmorphic RBCs. Hematuria in renal carcinoma is usually non-dysmorphic, as the blood is typically coming from a source like the renal parenchyma or urinary tract rather than from glomerular damage. C. Proximal tubule disease Diseases affecting the proximal tubule, such as acute tubular necrosis (ATN), do not typically cause dysmorphic RBCs. In ATN, the hematuria is usually non-dysmorphic, as the damage is to the tubular epithelial cells, not the glomeruli. RBCs that do appear in the urine are generally normal in shape. D. Distal tubule disease Similarly, diseases affecting the distal tubule, such as certain forms of interstitial nephritis, typically do not cause dysmorphic RBCs. Hematuria here is also usually non-dysmorphic because the source of the bleeding is more likely from the tubules or interstitium rather than from glomerular damage.

questions.text: Mesangial cells of IgA Nephropathy overexpresses:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) CD71. In IgA nephropathy, mesangial cells overexpress CD71, which is the transferrin receptor. This receptor plays a crucial role in iron uptake, and its overexpression in IgA nephropathy is thought to contribute to the pathogenesis of the disease by promoting inflammatory responses and mesangial cell proliferation. The overexpression of CD71 is linked to the chronic immune deposition seen in the mesangium, which is characteristic of IgA nephropathy. Explanation for Incorrect Answers: A. CD51 CD51 is also known as the integrin alpha-V subunit and is involved in cell adhesion, but it is not specifically overexpressed in IgA nephropathy. It plays a role in various other cellular processes and is not characteristic of mesangial cell changes in IgA nephropathy. B. CD61 CD61 is the integrin beta-3 subunit, which is involved in platelet aggregation and adhesion. It is not a marker that is typically overexpressed in mesangial cells of IgA nephropathy. Its role is more prominent in platelet biology than in the mesangial changes seen in IgA nephropathy. D. CD81 CD81 is a transmembrane protein that is involved in T-cell and B-cell signaling and is not specifically associated with mesangial cell changes in IgA nephropathy. Its overexpression is not linked to the pathogenesis of this disease.

choices.text: Finely granular along the perimesangial reflections
Linear along the glomerular basement membrane

questions.text: A 35-year-old man with a history of smoking presents with hematuria and bloody sputum. Over the next 2 days, he develops oliguria and renal failure, after which he is placed on dialysis. A renal biopsy is stained with fluorescein-conjugated goat antihuman IgG, and the results are shown. Which of the following best describes the pattern of direct immunofluorescence observed on this photomicrograph?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Linear along the glomerular basement membrane. The clinical presentation of hematuria, bloody sputum, and renal failure in a 35-year-old man with a history of smoking suggests a diagnosis of Goodpasture syndrome, which involves anti-glomerular basement membrane (GBM) antibodies. On direct immunofluorescence, the characteristic finding in Goodpasture syndrome is a linear pattern of IgG deposition along the glomerular basement membrane (GBM), reflecting the direct binding of autoantibodies to the GBM. This pattern is diagnostic and supports the diagnosis of anti-GBM disease, a form of rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis. Explanation for Incorrect Answers: A. Discontinuous and peripheral A discontinuous and peripheral pattern of immunofluorescence would typically suggest diseases like lupus nephritis or membranous nephropathy, where immune complexes deposit in a more patchy or peripheral distribution. This is not consistent with the linear deposition seen in Goodpasture syndrome. B. Finely granular along the perimesangial reflections A finely granular pattern along the perimesangial reflections is characteristic of IgA nephropathy. This disease presents with mesangial immune complex deposition, not with the linear GBM pattern seen in Goodpasture syndrome. D. Mesangial with a stalk predominance A mesangial pattern with stalk predominance is typically seen in diseases like IgA nephropathy or membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis (MPGN). These diseases show mesangial deposition of immunoglobulins or complement, but this is not the finding in Goodpasture syndrome, which involves linear deposition along the GBM.

questions.text: Berger nephropathy is due to mesangial deposition of
questions.solution: Corrrect Answer (D) IgA and C3. Berger nephropathy, also known as IgA nephropathy, is characterized by the mesangial deposition of IgA and C3 in the glomeruli. The disease often presents with hematuria and is associated with IgA immune complex deposition in the mesangium of the glomeruli. This deposition leads to inflammation and can cause progressive kidney damage. The presence of C3 alongside IgA is a hallmark of this disease, as it suggests activation of the complement system as part of the immune response. Explanation for Incorrect Answers: A. Fibrin and C3 Fibrin deposition is not a characteristic feature of IgA nephropathy. Instead, fibrin deposition can be seen in conditions like glomerulonephritis with thrombosis or other forms of vasculitis. IgA deposition is the primary hallmark of Berger nephropathy, not fibrin. B. IgD and C3 IgD is not typically involved in IgA nephropathy. While IgD can be found in certain rare immune-related conditions, it is not associated with IgA nephropathy, where the key immunoglobulin is IgA, along with C3 complement. C. IgE and C3 IgE is mainly associated with allergic reactions and parasitic infections, but it is not involved in the pathogenesis of IgA nephropathy. The predominant immunoglobulin in Berger nephropathy is IgA, not IgE. Thus, this option is incorrect.

questions.text: In IgA nephropathy (Berger’s disease) there are
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) I gA nephropathy is an example of mesangioproliferative glomerulonephritis

questions.text: Kimmelstiel-Wilson lesions in kidney consists
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Ovoid, spherical, laminated hyaline masses in periphery of glomerulus, PAS+, eventually obliterates glomerular tuft; specific for diabetes Can also be seen in membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis, light chain disease and amyloidosis

questions.text: Pauci immune glomerulonephritis is seen in:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Microscopic polyangiitis. Pauci-immune glomerulonephritis is a type of glomerulonephritis characterized by the absence or minimal deposition of immune complexes on immunofluorescence. It is commonly seen in small-vessel vasculitis diseases, such as microscopic polyangiitis (MPA) and granulomatosis with polyangiitis (GPA) (formerly known as Wegener's granulomatosis). In MPA, there is ANCA-associated pauci-immune glomerulonephritis, where the immune response is primarily directed against neutrophils (via anti-neutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies, or ANCA), not immune complex deposition. This leads to the characteristic pauci-immune pattern in renal biopsies. Explanation for Incorrect Answers: A. After transplant in Alports Alport syndrome is a genetic condition affecting the collagen of the glomerular basement membrane, leading to progressive kidney disease. After renal transplant, patients with Alport syndrome may develop glomerulonephritis, but it is typically immune-complex mediated, not pauci-immune. The kidney biopsy would show deposition of immune complexes, and thus not meet the criteria for pauci-immune glomerulonephritis. C. Henoch-Schönlein nephritis Henoch-Schönlein purpura (HSP) is a vasculitis that involves IgA deposition in the kidneys (as seen in IgA nephropathy). It is an immune-complex mediated disease and does not show the pauci-immune pattern. HSP would show mesangial IgA deposition on immunofluorescence, which distinguishes it from pauci-immune glomerulonephritis. D. Lupus nephritis Lupus nephritis is characterized by immune-complex deposition, with IgG, IgM, and C3 often being present in the glomeruli. The disease typically shows a full-house immunofluorescence pattern, with widespread deposition of various immunoglobulins and complement components, not the pauci-immune pattern seen in MPA.

questions.text: Mutation in NPHS1 gene causes which disease?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Congenital Finnish type nephrotic syndrome. A mutation in the NPHS1 gene is associated with Congenital Finnish type nephrotic syndrome (also known as Finnish nephrotic syndrome). The NPHS1 gene encodes nephrin, a key protein that is part of the slit diaphragm in the glomerular filtration barrier. Mutations in this gene result in a disruption of the filtration barrier, leading to proteinuria, edema, and early onset nephrotic syndrome, often presenting in the first year of life. This condition is most commonly seen in individuals of Finnish descent. Explanation for Incorrect Answers: A. Alport syndrome Alport syndrome is caused by mutations in the COL4A5, COL4A3, or COL4A4 genes, which encode collagen IV proteins, not the NPHS1 gene. This syndrome typically leads to glomerulonephritis, sensorineural hearing loss, and ocular abnormalities, and is not associated with mutations in the NPHS1 gene. C. Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS) is a condition characterized by scarring of some glomeruli. It can be idiopathic or secondary to various causes, but it is not typically linked to mutations in the NPHS1 gene. FSGS is often associated with other genetic mutations, such as those affecting the NPHS2 gene (encoding podocin), rather than NPHS1. D. Nail-patella syndrome Nail-patella syndrome is caused by mutations in the LMX1B gene, not NPHS1. It is characterized by abnormalities in the nails, patella, and other skeletal features, along with kidney problems. However, the mutation in NPHS1 is not responsible for this condition.

questions.text: Broad cast is characteristic of
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Broad casts or "renal failure' casts are formed in the collecting ducts as the result of urinary stasis and are two to six times the size of other types of casts. Broad casts are typically seen in patients with chronic renal failure.

questions.text: Cast is produced in
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Eosinophilic hyaline casts, as well as pigmented granular casts, are common, particularly in distal tubules and collecting ducts. These casts consist principally of Tamm-Horsfall protein (a urinary glycoprotein normally secreted by the cells of ascending thick limb and distal tubules) in conjunction with other plasma proteins

questions.text: Maximum endocapillary proliferation is a feature of
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSGN). Post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis is characterized by maximum endocapillary proliferation in the glomeruli. This is a result of the immune response following a streptococcal infection, typically of the throat or skin. In PSGN, there is an acute inflammatory response, leading to proliferation of endothelial cells and inflammatory cells within the capillary loops (endocapillary proliferation). This is a distinctive feature seen on renal biopsy, alongside other findings like humps of immune complexes on electron microscopy. Explanation for Incorrect Answers: A. Membranous GN In membranous glomerulonephritis, the key feature is thickening of the glomerular basement membrane due to immune complex deposition, not endocapillary proliferation. There may be some mesangial proliferation, but the defining feature is the subepithelial deposition of immune complexes, not endocapillary changes. B. Mesangioproliferative Mesangioproliferative glomerulonephritis typically involves proliferation of mesangial cells and matrix in the glomeruli. This type of glomerulonephritis can be seen in IgA nephropathy and some other diseases but does not show the endocapillary proliferation that is characteristic of post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis. C. Focal glomerulosclerosis In focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS), there is segmental scarring of glomeruli, often with some degree of podocyte injury. It does not typically feature endocapillary proliferation, and the primary pathology involves glomerular sclerosis rather than inflammation of the capillary loops.

questions.text: Rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis is histologically characterised by the presence of numerous
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Crescents are formed by proliferation of parietal cells and by migration of monocytes and macrophages into the urinary space. Neutrophils and lymphocytes may be present. The crescents may obliterate the urinary space and compress the glomerular tuft. Fibrin strands are frequently prominent between the cellular layers in the crescents

questions.text: Crescent are derived from
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Crescents are formed by proliferation of parietal cells and by migration of monocytes and macrophages into the urinary space. Neutrophils and lymphocytes may be present. The crescents may obliterate the urinary space and compress the glomerular tuft. Fibrin strands are frequently prominent between the cellular layers in the crescents

questions.text: Malignancies are most commonly associated with which type of Glomerulonephritis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Membranous glomerulonephritis (MGN). Malignancies are most commonly associated with membranous glomerulonephritis (MGN). MGN is a type of nephrotic syndrome characterized by the deposition of immune complexes in the subepithelial space of the glomerular basement membrane. This condition has been strongly linked to various malignancies, particularly solid tumors such as lung, colon, breast, and kidney cancers. The relationship between malignancy and MGN is thought to involve the production of tumor-associated antigens that trigger immune complex formation, leading to glomerular injury. Explanation for Incorrect Answers: B. MPGN (Membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis) While MPGN can be associated with chronic infections and autoimmune diseases, it is not as commonly linked to malignancies as MGN. MPGN involves mesangial proliferation and thickening of the glomerular basement membrane, but malignancy-related cases are less frequent compared to MGN. C. Minimal change disease Minimal change disease (MCD) is primarily associated with nephrotic syndrome in children, and while it may occasionally occur in adults, it is not strongly linked to malignancy. The exact cause of MCD remains unclear, but it is most often seen in the context of allergic reactions, infections, or drug use rather than malignancies. D. FSGS (Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis) FSGS can sometimes be secondary to other conditions, including obesity, HIV, and heroin use, but it is not as strongly associated with malignancies as MGN. FSGS is a condition characterized by scarring of some glomeruli, and although it can be secondary to various causes, it is less frequently seen in the context of malignancy.

questions.text: Most common cause of death in APCKD (ADULT POLYCYSTIC KIDNEY DISEASE)-
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Cardiovascular disease. In adult polycystic kidney disease (APCKD), also known as autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD), the most common cause of death is cardiovascular disease. Patients with ADPKD often have hypertension, which is common due to the cystic expansion of the kidneys and compression of blood vessels. Over time, this leads to cardiovascular complications such as heart failure, arrhythmias, and stroke. The high incidence of cardiovascular disease in these patients is considered a primary cause of mortality, even before renal failure becomes end-stage. Explanation for Incorrect Answers: A. Chronic renal failure Chronic renal failure is indeed a significant concern in ADPKD, and many patients will eventually develop end-stage renal disease (ESRD). However, cardiovascular disease precedes renal failure as the leading cause of death in these patients. While renal failure is a major complication of ADPKD, it is not the most immediate cause of death. C. Ruptured berry aneurysm Ruptured berry aneurysm (intracranial aneurysm) is a well-known risk in ADPKD patients due to their increased propensity for aneurysms, particularly in the circle of Willis. While a ruptured aneurysm can be fatal, it is less common than cardiovascular disease as the leading cause of death. Aneurysm rupture is certainly a risk, but it is not the most frequent cause of mortality. D. Sepsis Sepsis can occur in ADPKD, especially in patients with urinary tract infections or kidney stones. However, it is a less common cause of death compared to cardiovascular disease. The increased risk of infections can contribute to morbidity but is not the most frequent cause of mortality in these patients.

questions.text: The mother of a 2-month-old child palpates a mass on the left side of the child’s abdomen. Vital signs are normal. A CT-guided renal biopsy shows undifferentiated tubules surrounded by undifferentiated mesenchyme, smooth muscle, and islands of cartilage. The mass is removed (shown in the image) and displays variably sized cysts. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis for this child’s flank mass
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Young child- abdominal mass- undifferentiated tubules, mesenchyme etc- suggestive of dysplastic changes in kidney Multicystic dysplastic kidney is the most common cause of abdominal MASS in infants

choices.text: Granular deposits along the basement membranes
Linear staining along the glomerular basement membranes

questions.text: An 8-year-old boy presents with headaches, dizziness, and malaise approximately 2 weeks after a severe sore throat. His mother describes puffiness of his face and darkening of his urine. She also notes that her son is passing less urine and that he is becoming increasingly short of breath. On physical examination, there is anasarca, hypertension (190/130 mm Hg), and tachycardia. The urine is scanty and brownish red. Urinalysis shows 3+ proteinuria. Microscopic examination of the urine discloses numerous RBCs, as well as occasional granular and red cell casts. A renal biopsy is stained by direct immunofluorescence microscopy for complement C3, and the results are shown. Which of the following best describes the pattern of immune-fluorescence observed in this renal biopsy?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Young boy + 2 weeks post throat infection + puffiness of face (edema) + darkening of urine (hematuria) Less urine- oliguria (setting in failure) All urine findings suggestive of nephritic syndrome due to PSGN IF shows granular immunofluorescence (linear appears ribbon like while this has a coarse texture) Option D are seen on electron microscopy and not on IF

questions.text: Type of renal cell carcinoma seen in sickle cell trait is
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Medullary. Medullary renal cell carcinoma is the type of kidney cancer most commonly associated with sickle cell trait. This rare and aggressive form of renal cell carcinoma typically occurs in individuals with sickle cell trait or sickle cell disease. It arises in the renal medulla and is characterized by the presence of a distinctive poorly differentiated tumor. The exact mechanisms by which sickle cell trait predisposes to medullary carcinoma are not completely understood, but it is thought that the hypoxic environment in the renal medulla, caused by sickling of red blood cells, may contribute to the development of this carcinoma. Explanation for Incorrect Answers: A. Chromophobe Chromophobe renal cell carcinoma is a distinct subtype of renal cell carcinoma but is not associated with sickle cell trait. It is thought to arise from intercalated cells of the renal tubules and is typically characterized by pale, granular cytoplasm and relatively favorable prognosis. It is not linked to sickle cell disease or trait. B. Clear cell Clear cell renal cell carcinoma is the most common subtype of renal cell carcinoma overall, but it is not specifically linked to sickle cell trait. It arises from proximal tubular cells and is associated with mutations in the VHL gene. While clear cell carcinoma is a major type of renal cancer, it is not the one commonly associated with sickle cell trait. C. Papillary Papillary renal cell carcinoma is another subtype of renal cell carcinoma, often associated with mutations in the MET gene. It is more commonly seen in individuals with von Hippel-Lindau disease or those with chronic kidney disease, but it is not specifically associated with sickle cell trait. Like clear cell carcinoma, papillary carcinoma is not the type seen in sickle cell trait.

questions.text: Nephrotic syndrome is characterised by all except
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Haematuria. Nephrotic syndrome is characterized by a combination of clinical features resulting from damage to the glomerular filtration barrier. These include proteinuria, hyperlipidemia, and oedema. The key feature of nephrotic syndrome is the loss of large amounts of protein in the urine (usually more than 3.5 grams per day), leading to a reduction in plasma albumin, which in turn causes oedema. The liver compensates for the loss of albumin by producing more lipids, resulting in hyperlipidemia. Haematuria is typically not a hallmark feature of nephrotic syndrome, as this condition usually involves the leakage of proteins, not blood, into the urine. However, haematuria can occur in some conditions that can cause nephrotic syndrome, but it is not characteristic of the syndrome itself. Explanation for Incorrect Answers: A. Proteinuria Proteinuria is the hallmark feature of nephrotic syndrome. It occurs due to damage to the glomerular filtration barrier, which normally prevents the passage of large proteins (like albumin) into the urine. In nephrotic syndrome, proteinuria is usually more than 3.5 grams per day, leading to the clinical manifestations of the syndrome. B. Hyperlipidemia Hyperlipidemia is another key characteristic of nephrotic syndrome. In response to the low serum albumin levels due to protein loss in the urine, the liver increases production of lipoproteins, resulting in elevated levels of cholesterol and triglycerides in the blood. C. Oedema Oedema is a common feature of nephrotic syndrome. The loss of albumin leads to a decrease in oncotic pressure, causing fluid to leak into the interstitial spaces, resulting in swelling, particularly in the legs, abdomen (ascites), and face (periorbital oedema).

questions.text: Hypercoagulation in nephrotic syndrome is due to syndrome is caused by
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Thrombotic and thromboembolic complications are also common in nephrotic syndrome, due in part to loss of endogenous anticoagulants (e.g., antithrombin III) in the urine. Renal vein thrombosis, once thought to be a cause of nephrotic syndrome, is most often a consequence of this hypercoagulable state, particularly in patients with membranous nephropathy

questions.text: True about light microscopy in minimal change disease is
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) No change seen. In minimal change disease (MCD), light microscopy typically shows no significant changes in the glomeruli. The condition is characterized by normal-appearing glomeruli on light microscopy, which is why it is called "minimal change." The pathologic hallmark of MCD is the loss of podocyte foot processes, which is most visible on electron microscopy, not light microscopy. The condition is predominantly diagnosed based on the absence of significant findings on light microscopy, with the main clue coming from the clinical presentation of nephrotic syndrome and the findings on electron microscopy. Explanation for Incorrect Answers: A. Loss of foot process seen The loss of foot processes is a key finding in minimal change disease, but it is seen on electron microscopy, not light microscopy. On light microscopy, there are no noticeable changes in the glomeruli, which is why the disease is called minimal change. The loss of foot processes leads to increased permeability to proteins, resulting in proteinuria characteristic of MCD. B. Anti GBM Abs seen Anti-glomerular basement membrane (GBM) antibodies are associated with Goodpasture syndrome, which involves anti-GBM glomerulonephritis, not minimal change disease. In MCD, there is no involvement of autoimmune antibodies like anti-GBM, which distinguishes it from diseases like Goodpasture syndrome or other forms of glomerulonephritis. C. IgA deposits seen IgA deposits are typically seen in IgA nephropathy, not in minimal change disease. MCD is not associated with immune complex deposition, which is the hallmark of IgA nephropathy. The pathophysiology of MCD involves podocyte dysfunction and is not related to the deposition of immunoglobulins like IgA.

questions.text: A 3-years old child develops severe generalized edema following a viral infection. On the basis of clinical chemistry tests, a renal biopsy is performed, with normal light microscopic findings. Which of the following abnormal laboratory values might be expected in this individual?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Low serum albumin levels This child has minimal change disease, which is the major cause (more than 90% of cases) of nephrotic syndrome in children aged 2-6 years. The most prominent clinical chemistry finding in these patients is massive proteinuria. The urinary protein in minimal change disease, in contrast to other causes of nephrotic syndrome, is often composed predominantly of albumin. Many other clinical chemistry changes may also be seen, including decreased serum albumin levels, hyperlipidemia, increased serum levels of alpha2-and beta-globulins, decreased IgG, and increased fibrinogen. Minimal change disease characteristically shows normal or near normal appearance of the glomeruli by light microscopy and extensive fusion of foot processes of the glomerular podocytes by electron microscopy. A point not always recognized by beginners is that the podocyte alterations may represent a reaction to, rather than a cause of, the proteinuria (e.g., an attempt to “seal the holes” in the glomerulus), since varying degrees of foot process fusion (together with more specific features) may sometimes be seen in other glomerular diseases associated with the nephrotic syndrome. Since light microscopy is normal in minimal change disease, it is known as "NIL LESION"

questions.text: A severely ill patient in shock develops acute renal failure with oliguria and azotemia. The urine osmolality approaches that of the glomerular ultrafiltrate (specific gravity 1.010). A renal biopsy would most likely show which of the following?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Acute tubular necrosis This is the atypical clinical scenario in which acute tubular necrosis develops secondary to shock, and further destabilizes an already desperately ill patient. Acute tubular necrosis can also occur following exposure to nephrotoxins or as a manifestation of acute rejection in a transplanted kidney. The prognosis depends on the patient’s overall health. In patients who recover, the initial oliguric phase (lasting 1-2 weeks) is followed by a diuretic phase (weeks to months) before eventual restoration of tubular function.

questions.text: Following an upper respiratory infection, a 5-years-old develops large purpuric lesions on the buttocks and extensor surfaces of the arms and legs. The patient also has abdominal pain, vomiting, and arthralgias. Dipstick analysis of the urine shows microscopic hematuria. Renal biopsy would probably show which of the following distinctive features?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) IgA in the mesangial region The presentation in the question stem is classic for Henoch-Schonlein purpura. The distinctive renal biopsy finding is deposition of IgA (together with IgG and complement) in the mesangium of the glomeru. IgA can also be present in small dermal vessels within the characteristic skin lesion, which consist of subepidermal hemorrhages with necrotizing vasculitis.

choices.text: Increase ammonia concentration in the urine

questions.text: An abdominal x-ray performed on a 54-years old man demonstrates a large, irregular calcified mass with multiple broad projections filling one renal pelvis. Which of the following laboratory findings might be expected in this patient?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Increased ammonia concentration in the urine. This case describes a staghorn calculus, which is a large, irregular calcified mass with broad projections filling the renal pelvis. Such stones are often composed of struvite (magnesium ammonium phosphate) and are typically associated with urinary tract infections caused by urease-producing bacteria (e.g., Proteus mirabilis, Klebsiella). These bacteria hydrolyze urea into ammonia and carbon dioxide, leading to an increase in urine pH (alkalinity) and ammonia concentration. The high ammonia concentration combines with magnesium and phosphate to form struvite stones. Increased ammonia in the urine is a hallmark finding in these cases. Explanation for the Incorrect Options: A. Decreased urine pH: Struvite stones are associated with alkaline urine (high pH), not acidic urine (low pH). Urease-producing bacteria elevate urine pH by increasing ammonia production. Thus, this finding is inconsistent with the patient's condition. B. Hypercalcemia: Hypercalcemia is associated with calcium oxalate or calcium phosphate stones, not struvite stones. While hypercalcemia increases the risk of nephrolithiasis, it is not relevant to this case, as the stone's morphology and association with infection suggest a struvite composition. C. Hyperuricemia: Hyperuricemia is associated with uric acid stones, which are radiolucent (not visible on x-ray). Uric acid stones form in acidic urine, unlike the struvite stones described here, which are visible on x-ray and form in alkaline urine.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man has experienced increasing malaise, nausea,and reduced urine output for the past 3 days. On physical examination, he is afebrile and normotensive. Laboratory findings show a serum creatinine level of 7.5 mg/dL. Urinalysis shows hematuria,but no pyuria or glucosuria. A renal biopsy is done; the light microscopic picture is shown in the figure. Which of the following additional studies is most useful for classification and treatment of this disease?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Anti–glomerular basement membrane antibody The figure shows glomeruli with epithelial crescents indicative of a rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis. Crescentic GN is divided into three groups on the basis of immunofluorescence: Type I (anti–glomerular basement membrane [GBM] disease); Type II (immune complex disease); Type III (characterized by the absence of anti-GBM antibodies or immune complexes). The presence of anti-GBM antibodies suggests Goodpasture syndrome; patients with this disorder require plasmapheresis.Type II crescentic GN can occur in systemic lupus erythematosus, in Henoch-Schönlein purpura, and after infections. Causes of type III crescentic GN include granulomatosis with polyangiitis (ANCA-associated vasculitis) and microscopic polyangiitis.

questions.text: A 21-year-old previously healthy man has noticed blood in his urine for the past 2 days. He reports no dysuria,frequency, or hesitancy of urination. On physical examination, there are no abnormal findings. Laboratory findings show a serum urea nitrogen level of 39 mg/dL and creatinine level of 4.1 mg/dL. A renal biopsy specimen is obtained; the immunofluorescence pattern of staining with antibody against human IgG is shown in the figure. Which of the following serologic findings is most likely to be present in this patient?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Anti–glomerular basement membrane antibody The linear pattern of staining shown in the figure indicates the presence of anti–glomerular basement membrane antibodies (directed against the non collagenous domain of the α3 chain of type IV collagen). Such antibodies are typically seen in Goodpasture syndrome, a form of rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis (GN) that has a bimodal pattern of occurrence in younger and older men. The anti–streptolysin O titer is increased in poststreptococcal GN, which typically has a granular pattern of immune complex deposition. The C3 nephritic factor can be a marker for dense deposit disease.

choices.text: Adult form shows an autosomal-recessive pattern of inheritance
Cysts initially involve only portion of a nephron
Mutations in PKD1 occur in 85% of patients

questions.text: A nephrectomy specimen from a 40-year-old man is shown. Both the kidneys have a similar appearance. Which of the following statements does not apply to this condition?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Adult form shows an autosomal-recessive pattern of inheritance Adult form shows an autosomal-recessive pattern of inheritance. The specimen shows an enlarged multicystic kidney, with cysts distributed throughout the cortex and medulla, without any identifiable residual parenchyma. The age of the patient and bilateral involvement are consistent with adult polycystic kidney disease. The adult form is inherited as an autosomal-dominant disease, while the childhood polycystic disease shows an autosomal-recessive mode of inheritance. Grossly, the autosomal- recessive form shows smaller cysts with dilated channels that are usually oriented perpendicular to the renal cortical surface. As the cysts initially involve only part of the nephron, the renal function is preserved until the 4th or 5th decade of life.

questions.text: A biopsy from a patient with active lupus nephritis. Based on the pattern of disease shown here, in which of the following portions of the nephron are the immune complexes typically deposited?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Subendothelial. The figure shows the characteristic wire-loop lesions of lupus nephritis associated with class IV disease. Electron microscopy typically shows deposition of extensive and confluent electron-dense immune complexes within the subendothelial space. The glomerular lesions in SLE are due to deposition of immune complexes in the mesangium or glomerular basement membrane (GBM). The five main histologic patterns of lupus include minimal mesangial (class I), mesangial proliferative (class II), focal proliferative (class III), diffuse proliferative (class IV), and membranous (class V). Classes I and II show mesangial deposits of immune complexes, while class III and beyond show progressively severe involvement of the glomeruli with crescent formation, fibrinoid necrosis, proliferation of endothelial and mesangial cells, infiltrating leukocytes, and eosinophilic deposits, or intracapillary thrombi. Immune complex deposits may be mesangial, intramembranous, subepithelial, and/or subendothelial in location. Class V or membranous form shows subepithelial deposits. Classes III and IV show subendothelial deposits. Extensive subendothelial deposits cause homogeneous thickening of the capillary wall, giving rise to the so-called “wire-loop” lesions. Presence of these lesions indicates active disease.

choices.text: Increased hydrostatic pressure due to arteriolar dilatation
Increased hydrostatic pressure due to impaired venous return

questions.text: A patient with kidney disease and nephrotic syndrome has severe pitting edema in his lower legs. This edema is primarily caused by which of the following processes?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Reduced plasma osmotic pressure Edema can be caused by an imbalance in solutes, plasma osmotic pressure, or hydrostatic pressure. Nephrotic syndrome can be caused by a variety of diseases; the photomicrograph in this example is suggestive of minimal change disease, with effacement of the normal podocyte foot structure (arrows) around capillary lumens (CL). In nephrotic syndrome, excessive albumin and protein are lost from the kidneys into the urine. This results in reduced plasma osmotic pressure, which results in movement of water from the plasma in extracellular tissues. Reduced plasma osmotic pressure can also be caused by reduced synthesis of plasma proteins, which occurs in liver failure (cirrhosis) or starvation.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man with hypertension and nephrotic syndrome undergoes a renal biopsy. The appearance of the biopsy is similar to that shown in the figure.Of the following possible additional laboratory findings, which one is most characteristically associated with this lesion?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) The image shows nodular glomerulosclerosis (Kimmelstiel-Wilson nodules), the most characteristic glomerular finding in diabetes mellitus. The nodules are accumulations of mesangial matrix-like material.

choices.text: “Spike and dome” appearance of the glomerular basement membrane

questions.text: A 25-year-old man presents with hematuria, periorbital edema, hypertension, and hemoptysis. He has also experienced nausea, vomiting, fever, and chills. Serologic testing is positive for anti glomerular basement membrane antibodies. Which of the following is the classic histologic finding in this renal disease?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) The clinical description is that of Goodpasture syndrome (anti glomerular basement membrane disease), caused by antibodies directed against antigens in the glomerular and pulmonary alveolar basement membranes. Because antigens are an intrinsic component of the basement membrane, labeled antibodies “paint” the surface of the basement membrane, resulting in the characteristic linear immunofluorescence pattern characteristic of this disorder. “Lumpy-bumpy” immunofluorescence is a very coarse, granular immunofluorescence found in poststreptococcal immune complex deposit disease. The tram-track appearance is seen in membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis. The“spike and dome” appearance is seen in membranous glomerulonephritis. Subendothelial immune complex deposition is seen in lupus nephropathy.
